definition: The newton (N) is the SI-derived unit of force; one newton accelerates a one-kilogram mass by one metre per second squared.
The newton-metre (N·m) is the SI unit of torque, equal to one newton of force applied at a radius of one metre.
A newton per metre (N m-1) expresses surface tension or spring stiffness—one newton of force distributed over one metre of length.
Coulomb per square metre (C m-2) is the SI unit of surface charge density, indicating one coulomb of electric charge spread uniformly over one square metre.
The expression m²·m⁻² is dimensionless, representing a ratio of identical area terms that mathematically cancel to unity.
Mole per cubic metre (mol m-3) is the SI unit of amount-of-substance concentration, denoting one mole of entities in one cubic metre of volume.
The reciprocal ampere (A-1) indicates a quantity divided by electric current and appears in electromagnetic formulas that require normalisation by current.
The farad (F) is the SI-derived unit of capacitance: a conductor has a capacitance of one farad when one coulomb raises its potential by one volt.
The dalton (Da), or unified atomic mass unit, equals one-twelfth the mass of a carbon-12 atom and is used for atomic and molecular masses.
Second to the fourth power (s⁴) is a composite time unit that occurs in higher-order physical integrations and differential equations.
The reciprocal kilogram (kg-1) denotes a quantity normalised by mass, such as specific activity or attenuation coefficient per unit mass.
The radian (rad) is the SI unit of plane angle, defined as the angle subtended at a circle’s centre by an arc equal in length to the radius.
Joule per mole (J mol-1) expresses energy normalised to amount of substance and is common for molar enthalpy and Gibbs energy values.
The becquerel (Bq) is the SI unit of radioactivity, equal to one nuclear disintegration or similar stochastic event per second.
A byte (B) is a digital information unit consisting of eight bits and typically capable of representing one character in computer systems.
Coulomb per kilogram (C kg-1) measures ionising-radiation exposure as electric charge liberated per unit mass of air.
Ampere per square metre (A m-2) is the SI unit of current density, indicating electric current flowing per unit cross-sectional area.
Reciprocal kelvin (K-1) quantifies a property per unit temperature and is used, for example, in thermal expansion coefficients.
The joule (J) is the SI unit of work, energy and heat; one joule equals one newton-metre or one watt-second.
The square metre (m²) is the SI derived unit of area, equal to the area of a square with one-metre sides.
An electron volt (eV) is a non-SI energy unit equal to the kinetic energy gained by a single elementary charge when accelerated through a potential difference of one volt (≈1.602 × 10-19 J).
Joule per kilogram per kelvin (J kg-1 K-1) is the SI unit of specific heat capacity, describing energy required to raise the temperature of one kilogram of substance by one kelvin.
Reciprocal steradian (sr-1) is a dimensionless unit used when an intensive quantity is divided by solid angle.
Second per mole (s mol-1) indicates a time interval normalised by amount of substance and is useful in kinetics for average lifetime per mole.
Coulomb per cubic metre (C m-3) expresses volumetric charge density, the electric charge contained in a unit volume.
Joule per mole per kelvin (J mol-1 K-1) is the SI unit for molar entropy or molar heat capacity at constant pressure.
The lumen (lm) is the SI unit of luminous flux, defined as one candela-steradian, and measures perceived radiant power.
The hertz (Hz) is the SI unit of frequency, equal to one cycle or event per second.
Watt per metre per kelvin (W m-1 K-1) quantifies thermal conductivity—heat flow through a material one metre thick per kelvin temperature gradient.
A micrometre (µm) is a length of one-millionth of a metre, commonly used to express cell sizes and infrared wavelengths.
The gigapascal (GPa) equals one billion pascals and is widely used to state high pressures and elastic moduli.
The megapascal (MPa) equals one million pascals and is typically used for material strength and hydraulic pressures.
Reciprocal second (s-1) is a dimensionless unit for rates and frequencies, numerically identical to the hertz.
The degree Fahrenheit (°F) is a temperature scale where water freezes at 32 °F and boils at 212 °F under standard conditions.
The tesla (T) is the SI unit of magnetic flux density, defined as one weber per square metre.
The watt (W) is the SI unit of power, equivalent to one joule per second.
Gray per second (Gy s-1) expresses absorbed dose rate—the amount of ionising-radiation energy deposited per unit mass each second.
